title: Stainless Steel Plate Price Trend - Market Overview & Business Insights
description: The Stainless Steel Plate Price Trend has emerged as a critical metric for manufacturers, construction firms, engineering contractors, fabrication units, and procurement managers across the globe. As stainless steel remains a core material for infrastructure, energy, petrochemicals, machinery, and consumer
content: Stainless Steel Plate Price Trend - Market Overview & Business Insights 11-14-2025 01:11 PM CET | Industry, Real Estate & Construction Press release from: Procurement Resource The Stainless Steel Plate Price Trend has emerged as a critical metric for manufacturers, construction firms, engineering contractors, fabrication units, and procurement managers across the globe. As stainless steel remains a core material for infrastructure, energy, petrochemicals, machinery, and consumer goods, understanding its price movement is essential for cost planning, project forecasting, and strategic sourcing. Request for Real-Time Prices:- In 2025, the market for stainless steel plates continues to evolve rapidly due to shifting global demand, raw material volatility, technological advancements in steel production, and momentum toward sustainable manufacturing. Businesses that track these price trends closely gain a competitive advantage by optimizing procurement cycles, reducing risks, and securing the best value from suppliers. Market Overview Stainless steel plates are produced in various grades-such as 304, 316, 310, and 321-each catering to different industrial requirements. Their pricing is directly linked to: Raw material costs, particularly nickel, chromium, iron ore, and molybdenum Regional supply-demand dynamics Energy prices and production costs Import-export policies and tariffs Global macroeconomic trends Over the past few quarters, stainless steel plate prices have shown mixed movement. While some regions experienced upward pressure due to energy costs and raw material constraints, others saw stabilization driven by improved supply chains and enhanced production capacities. Key Factors Influencing Stainless Steel Plate Price Trend 1. Nickel and Chromium Prices Nickel is the most influential raw material in stainless steel production, especially for austenitic grades like 304 and 316. When nickel prices fluctuate-even by small margins-the impact on stainless steel plate pricing is immediate. Similarly, chromium contributes significantly to corrosion resistance. Any shortage or policy-driven price surge results in upward pressure on stainless steel plate costs. 2. Energy and Production Costs Stainless steel manufacturing is energy-intensive. Rising electricity, natural gas, and coal prices increase mill-level production expenditures. Some countries have introduced carbon taxes and environmental compliance requirements, further pushing costs upward. Regions with stable energy prices or renewable energy integration often benefit from more consistent stainless steel pricing. 3. Demand from Construction and Infrastructure Construction and infrastructure development remain the backbone of stainless steel consumption. Large-scale metro projects, bridges, smart city initiatives, and public infrastructure directly impact stainless steel plate demand. With global infrastructure spending projected to rise in 2025, many regions expect moderate to strong demand, contributing to firm pricing. 4. Import-Export Regulations and Anti-Dumping Duties Price trends are heavily influenced by government policies. Several major economies impose anti-dumping duties on imported stainless steel to protect domestic industries. These policies alter supply dynamics, sometimes limiting availability or causing temporary price hikes. 5. Manufacturing Capacity and Supply Chain Stability Supply disruptions-such as logistics shortages, port congestion, or geopolitical restrictions-quickly affect stainless steel plate prices. Many countries have expanded production to address supply gaps, resulting in some price normalization. Regional Stainless Steel Plate Price Trend Analysis Asia-Pacific (APAC) The APAC region dominates stainless steel plate production, with China and India at the forefront. Increased manufacturing capacity and raw material accessibility offer competitive pricing. However, fluctuating nickel prices continue to influence short-term volatility. India's stainless steel industry particularly benefits from government initiatives encouraging domestic manufacturing. Europe European prices are comparatively higher due to strict environmental regulations, high energy costs, and premium quality standards. The region sees steady demand from the automotive, machinery, and chemical industries. North America The U.S. stainless steel plate market is shaped by infrastructure investments and anti-dumping duties that protect domestic mills. Prices generally remain stable but higher than Asian markets due to labor and production costs. Middle East & Africa Gradual industrial growth and large-scale energy projects influence demand. Pricing varies depending on imports, as local production is still developing. Industry Applications Driving Demand 1. Construction & Infrastructure Stainless steel plates are widely used in structural components, bridges, industrial buildings, and architectural projects due to their durability and corrosion resistance. 2. Oil, Gas & Petrochemicals High-grade stainless steel plates are essential for pipelines, reactors, pressure vessels, and offshore equipment. 3. Food & Beverage Processing Hygiene standards require stainless steel plates in machinery, storage tanks, preparation surfaces, and food-grade containers. 4. Automotive & Railways The sector increasingly uses stainless steel for body parts, exhaust systems, cargo containers, and safety components. 5. Heavy Machinery & Industrial Equipment Fabrication units rely on stainless steel plates to build machine frames, heat exchangers, conveyors, and industrial storage units. Forecast for Stainless Steel Plate Price Trend (2025-2026) Analysts anticipate a moderately stable price outlook with short-term fluctuations due to nickel market volatility. Key forecasts include: Steady demand from construction, renewable energy, and petrochemical sectors Technological improvements in steel manufacturing reducing production costs Shift toward green steel influencing price structures Continued volatility in raw material markets due to geopolitical factors The overall expectation points toward controlled upward movement, especially for premium grades. Stainless Steel Plate Price Trend :- Procurement Insights for Businesses 1. Adopt Long-Term Contracts Locking in prices with reliable mills or distributors helps mitigate market volatility. 2. Monitor Raw Material Indexes Tracking LME nickel and chromium prices provides early indicators of movement. 3. Diversify Suppliers Having multiple regional suppliers ensures consistent availability and competitive pricing. 4. Evaluate Inventory Strategies Bulk purchasing during price dips helps reduce annual procurement expenditure. 5. Focus on Grade Optimization Choosing the right grade based on application prevents overspending. Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) 1. What is driving the Stainless Steel Plate Price Trend in 2025? The trend is influenced by nickel and chromium prices, demand from construction and energy sectors, energy costs, and government import policies. 2. Which stainless steel grade is most affected by nickel prices? Austenitic grades such as 304 and 316 are highly dependent on nickel, making them more vulnerable to price swings. 3. Which region currently offers the most competitive stainless steel plate prices? Asia-Pacific, particularly China and India, generally provides the most competitive pricing due to large-scale production capacities. 4. Will stainless steel plate prices increase in the coming months? Moderate price increases are possible due to rising global infrastructure demand and raw material fluctuations. However, production expansions may help stabilize costs. 5. How can businesses reduce procurement costs? Long-term contracts, monitoring raw material indexes, supplier diversification, and bulk purchasing during price dips can significantly reduce costs. 6. Are environmental regulations impacting stainless steel pricing? Yes. Countries with strict emission norms have higher production costs, influencing plate prices. 7. What industries consume the most stainless steel plates? Major consumers include construction, petrochemicals, heavy machinery, automotive, and food processing industries. title: Jaguar Land Rover plunges to loss after heavy cyber attack costs
description: JLR booked ¬£196 million of extra costs linked to the cyber attack and ¬£42 million related to voluntary redundancies.
content: Jaguar Land Rover has plunged to a heavy loss after booking almost ¬£200 million in costs linked to a major cyber attack which saw the firm shut its factories for more than a month. The UK‚Äôs largest car manufacturer said it has ‚Äúmade strong progress‚Äù in recovering its operations at pace since the attack. JLR stopped production across its UK factories for five weeks from September 1 after being targeted by hackers a day earlier. JLR stopped production across its UK factories for five weeks (Jaguar Land Rover/PA) All of the group‚Äôs manufacturing sites ‚Äì including factories in Solihull, West Midlands, and Halewood, Merseyside ‚Äì restarted operations last month. However, it saw revenues plummet by more than ¬£1 billion, around 24%, to ¬£4.9 billion for the quarter to September. It also swung to an underlying loss of ¬£485 million over the quarter, sliding from a profit before tax and exceptional items of nearly ¬£400 million over the same period in 2024. In the update, it booked ¬£196 million of extra costs linked to the cyber attack and ¬£42 million related to voluntary redundancies. The company said its performance was also impacted by US tariffs and a planned wind down in the production of previous Jaguar models.
creator: PA News Agency
ai_summary: Jaguar Land Rover reported a significant loss after a cyber attack led to a shutdown of its UK factories for over a month, resulting in ¬£196 million in extra costs and a ¬£1 billion drop in revenues. The company also faced ¬£42 million in voluntary redundancy costs, with additional impacts from US tariffs and the winding down of older Jaguar models.

title: Jaguar Land Rover plunges to loss after heavy cyber attack costs
description: JLR booked ¬£196 million of extra costs linked to the cyber attack and ¬£42 million related to voluntary redundancies.
content: The UK‚Äôs largest car manufacturer said it has ‚Äúmade strong progress‚Äù in recovering its operations at pace since the attack. JLR stopped production across its UK factories for five weeks from September 1 after being targeted by hackers a day earlier. All of the group‚Äôs manufacturing sites ‚Äì including factories in Solihull, West Midlands, and Halewood, Merseyside ‚Äì restarted operations last month. However, it saw revenues plummet by more than ¬£1 billion, around 24%, to ¬£4.9 billion for the quarter to September. It also swung to an underlying loss of ¬£485 million over the quarter, sliding from a profit before tax and exceptional items of nearly ¬£400 million over the same period in 2024. In the update, it booked ¬£196 million of extra costs linked to the cyber attack and ¬£42 million related to voluntary redundancies. The company said its performance was also impacted by US tariffs and a planned wind down in the production of previous Jaguar models.

title: South Korea says to ‚Äòmove forward‚Äô on nuclear subs with US
description: South Korea will "move forward" with the United States in building nuclear-powered submarines, President Lee Jae Myung said Friday, after a long-awaited security and trade agreement was finalised.The post South Korea says to ‚Äòmove forward‚Äô on nuclear subs with US appeared first on Vanguard News.
content: South Korea will ‚Äúmove forward‚Äù with the United States in building nuclear-powered submarines, President Lee Jae Myung said Friday, after a long-awaited security and trade agreement was finalised.Analysts say developing the atomic-powered vessels would mark a significant leap in Seoul‚Äôs naval and defence industrial base, allowing it to join a select group of countries with such vessels.‚ÄúOne of the greatest variables for our economy and security ‚Äî the bilateral negotiations on trade, tariffs and security ‚Äî has been finalised,‚Äù Lee told a news conference, adding the two countries had agreed to ‚Äúmove forward with building nuclear-powered submarines‚Äù.Seoul had secured ‚Äúsupport for expanding our authority over uranium enrichment and spent-fuel reprocessing‚Äù, he said.A joint fact sheet outlining the deal said both sides would ‚Äúcollaborate further through a shipbuilding working group‚Äù to ‚Äúincrease the number of US commercial ships and combat-ready US military vessels‚Äù.Beijing, on Thursday, voiced caution over a Washington-Seoul deal on nuclear submarine technology.The partnership ‚Äúgoes beyond a purely commercial partnership, directly touching on the global non-proliferation regime and the stability of the Korean Peninsula and the wider region,‚Äù Dai Bing, China‚Äôs ambassador to Seoul told reporters.Details remain murky on where the nuclear submarines will be built.US President Donald Trump said on social media last month that ‚ÄúSouth Korea will be building its Nuclear Powered Submarine in the Philadelphia Shipyards, right here in the good ol‚Äô U.S.A‚Äù.‚Äì Billions in investments ‚ÄìUS nuclear technology is among its most sensitive and tightly guarded military secrets.However, Seoul‚Äôs national security advisor Wi Sung-lac said on Friday that ‚Äúfrom start to finish, the leaders‚Äô discussion proceeded on the premise that construction would take place in South Korea‚Äù.‚ÄúSo the question of where construction will take place can now be considered settled,‚Äù he added.As part of the deal, South Korea has pledged to buy $25 billion-worth of US military equipment and plans to ‚Äúprovide comprehensive support for US Forces Korea amounting to $33 billion‚Äù.Details of a tariffs agreement were also announced.Trump unexpectedly declared at last month‚Äôs APEC summit that the two sides had reached a deal on an investment package and auto tariffs, before clarifying it was ‚Äúpretty much‚Äù finalised.Seoul later said the $350-billion agreement included $200 billion in cash investment and $150 billion in shipbuilding cooperation, adding that both sides agreed to keep reciprocal tariffs and lower auto tariffs at 15 percent.Semiconductor tariffs, however, were not included in the deal at the time.The fact sheet stated that South Korea‚Äôs semiconductor tariffs will be ‚Äúno less favorable than terms that may be offered in a future agreement covering a volume of semiconductor trade at least as large as Korea‚Äôs‚Äù, but did not give further details.South Korea is home to Samsung Electronics and SK hynix and produces a significant chunk of high-end chips that have become the lifeblood of the global economy, powering everything from smartphones to missiles.The country‚Äôs semiconductor exports reached a record high of $142 billion in 2024, accounting for more than a fifth of the country‚Äôs total exports.hs/ep/dan/jmThe post South Korea says to ‚Äòmove forward‚Äô on nuclear subs with US appeared first on Vanguard News.
ai_summary: South Korea and the United States have agreed to move forward with building nuclear-powered submarines, marking a significant advancement in Seoul's naval and defense capabilities. President Lee Jae Myung announced the finalization of a long-awaited security and trade agreement, which includes support for South Korea's authority over uranium enrichment and spent-fuel reprocessing. The deal also aims to increase the number of US commercial ships and military vessels through a shipbuilding working group. However, China has expressed caution regarding the implications for global non-proliferation and regional stability.

title: RBI allows 15-month time for exporters to bring in proceeds of overseas shipments
description: New Delhi, Nov 14 (PTI) The Reserve Bank has permitted exporters to bring proceeds of their shipments in 15 months
content: New Delhi, Nov 14 (PTI) The Reserve Bank has permitted exporters to bring proceeds of their shipments in 15 months as against the prevailing timeframe of 9 months in view of stress being faced by them. Exporters are facing issues due to a steep tariff imposed by the US on Indian shipments since August. The US imposed a steep 50 per cent tariff on goods from India, which took effect on August 27. Currently, the value of goods or software exports made by exporters is required to be realised fully and repatriated to the country within a period of nine months from the date of export. The changes have been made following amendments to the Foreign Exchange Management (Export of Goods & Services) Regulations. These regulations may be called the Foreign Exchange Management (Export of Goods and Services) (Second Amendment) Regulations, 2025, a gazette notification dated November 13 by RBI regional director Rohit P Das said. "They shall come into force from the date of their publication in the Official Gazette," it said. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) had extended this timeframe for exporters to 15 months during 2020 during the COVID-19 period. Earlier in the week, the government approved two schemes with a combined outlay of over Rs 45,000 crore for exporters, which are expected to help boost the country's outbound shipments and enhance the competitiveness of domestic goods in the global markets. The government on Wednesday approved the Export Promotion Mission (Rs 25,060 crore) and the Credit Guarantee Scheme (Rs 20,000 crore). Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday said the Export Promotion Mission (EPM) will improve export competitiveness, help MSMEs, first-time exporters and sectors that are labour-intensive. (This story has not been edited by THE WEEK and is auto-generated from PTI)
creator: PTI
ai_summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has extended the timeframe for exporters to repatriate proceeds of overseas shipments from 9 to 15 months, due to the US imposing a 50% tariff on Indian goods since August. This amendment, effective from November 13, 2025, follows the COVID-19 period extension in 2020. The government also approved two schemes totaling over Rs 45,000 crore to support exporters and enhance global competitiveness.

title: DBS and OCBC draw positive views, but UOB outlook tempered by provisions in Q3
description: The dimmer outlook for UOB comes after higher loan provisions dragged down its earnings for the quarter.
content: SINGAPORE - Analysts are positive on DBS and OCBC after the two banks posted strong third-quarter results, but more wary of UOB, whose earnings for the period were hit by higher loan provisions. They also cautioned that all three banks could face more pressure on lending margins as interest rates fall and earlier hedges expire, even though DBS‚Äôs hedging strategy has helped cushion the impact of lower Singapore and Hong Kong benchmark rates so far. Interest rate hedges are financial contracts that help banks keep earning a steady interest income even when market rates fall. The analysts added that an earnings rebound at UOB could be on the cards with its provision buffers now built up and credit costs expected to return to normal. Singapore‚Äôs three largest banks posted mixed third-quarter results last week, with DBS and OCBC beating forecasts, and UOB falling short of expectations on the back of a $1 billion hike in credit provisions. DBS‚Äôs group net interest income (NII) for the quarter was mostly unchanged from a year ago at $3.58 billion, due to strong deposit growth and hedging strategies. This was despite net interest margins (NIM) falling to 1.96 per cent from 2.11 per cent a year earlier. NIMs are the difference between what a bank earns from loans and what it pays on deposits. DBS shares hit a high of $55.59 on Nov 7. The stock closed down 0.41 per cent at $53.99 on Nov 14. However, as its hedges roll off, or expire, and interest rates continue to decline, the bank‚Äôs NIM is expected to come under pressure going forward, said Morningstar‚Äôs director of Asia equity research Lorraine Tan. This is because banks often use hedges to lock in higher interest rates for a period. But once they expire, the bank is exposed to the current, lower-rate environment, which can squeeze NIMs. Macquarie Group‚Äôs head of Asean equity research Jayden Vantarakis said DBS has a total of $200 billion in fixed rate assets and hedges, with $78 billion rolling off in 2026. ‚ÄúThe rates outlook presents a headwind, especially as the hedge book unwinds,‚Äù said Mr Vantarakis. In 2026, DBS expects total income to be around 2025 levels despite the lower interest rates, while net profit is expected to be slightly below 2025 levels. This is due to group NII forecast to come in slightly below 2025 levels. Still, Ms Tan of Morningstar said that DBS‚Äôs strong wealth franchise could cushion it from interest rate headwinds, while OCBC Investment Research and RHB said that the impact of lower rates and the lower NII projection are expected to be mitigated by deposit growth Analysts, however, are mixed on how much further DBS‚Äôs share rally can run. Ms Tan said that DBS shares are ‚Äúnot cheap‚Äù and appear ‚Äúovervalued‚Äù. ‚ÄúWe believe DBS‚Äô strength against peers has already been priced in, and shares are now overvalued trading at a 15 per cent premium to our valuation,‚Äù she said, citing a fair value estimate of $48. Raising its fair value estimate for DBS shares from $54 to $55, head of OCBC Investment Research Carmen Lee said that DBS‚Äôs capital return strategy should provide strong share price support. In 2026, DBS plans to increase its quarterly dividend payout to 81 cents per share, which includes a 6-cent increase in the ordinary dividend to 66 cents and a 15-cent capital return dividend. RHB kept its ‚Äúbuy‚Äù call on DBS with a target price of $59, saying the bank‚Äôs dividend and capital return thesis remains intact. Mr Vantarakis of Macquarie however, reckons DBS will underperform, and expects its shares to be worth $46 in 12 months. At UOB, credit provisions jumped more than fourfold to $1.36 billion from $304 million a year earlier, as the bank bolstered coverage amid ongoing macro and sector-specific headwinds. That lifted its general allowance coverage to 1 per cent of performing loans. UOB said that its dividend payment would not be affected by the pre-emptive general allowance. Credit costs, which surged to 134 basis points in the third quarter from 36 basis points a year earlier, are expected to fall back to 25 to 30 basis points in the fourth quarter and into 2026. RHB noted that while the hike in provisions has made a dent in UOB‚Äôs profits, 2026 earnings should see a rebound given that the provision buffers are built up and credit costs are expected to return to normal levels. The bank kept its ‚Äúneutral rating‚Äù on the stock at a target price of $36.10. Mr Vantarakis of Macquarie said the firm believes provisions are now adequate, but added that investors will look out for normalisation. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear that a lot of scepticism remains, which means that a couple of quarters of normal provisions will be required for stock outperformance,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe upgrade from underperform to neutral as the large provision charge in third quarter 2025 clears the decks for better sequential performance,‚Äù he added. CreditSights senior analyst Karen Wu noted that UOB‚Äôs pre-tax profits in the first nine months of 2025 would still fall 16 per cent year on year, even after stripping out the impact of the extra general provisions. UOB‚Äôs conservative credit cost guidance of 25-30 basis points for fourth quarter and 2026 ‚Äì higher than its peers ‚Äì indicates limited room for general provision write-backs, she added. Ms Lee from OCBC Investment Research added that UOB‚Äôs recent share price drop offers an opportunity to accumulate the stock, which she estimates has a fair value of $38.20. The stock fell 0.29 per cent to close at $34 on Nov 14. Meanwhile, OCBC emerged as a standout among the three banks, with analysts citing robust NII and solid wealth momentum that stood out among its peers. Ms Wu of CreditSights said the bank‚Äôs strong non-interest income growth amid exceptionally high net new money inflows, which boosted wealth management fees, more than offset weaker NII and higher provisions at OCBC. The bank‚Äôs third quarter non-interest income rose 15 per cent year on year to $1.57 billion from fee, trading and insurance income growth. This helped keep net profit steady at $1.98 billion, largely unchanged from $1.97 billion a year earlier, and which beat a $1.79 billion forecast in a Bloomberg poll. Mr Vantakaris said that OCBC‚Äôs wealth momentum, measured by fee growth and assets under management increase, was the highest amongst peers, setting a strong base for 2026. ‚ÄúOCBC is our preference amongst the Singapore banks, over DBS and UOB. The balance sheet is most defensively positioned in terms of exposure to trade and general allowances.‚Äù ‚ÄúGuidance has also been conservative, presenting less risk to the outlook relative to peers,‚Äù he said. The analyst is upgrading OCBC to ‚Äúoutperform‚Äù with a 12-month target price of $19.90. Ms Tan of Morningstar said that OCBC‚Äôs third-quarter annualised credit cost remains low at 16 basis points, mostly consisting of special provisions, as the bank had already provided for macroeconomic risks related to tariffs earlier this year. ‚ÄúWith general allowance coverage of 0.9 per cent, we don‚Äôt expect sizable provisions going forward,‚Äù she said. OCBC shares closed down 0.75 per cent to $18.52 on Nov 14.
creator: The Straits Times
ai_summary: Singapore's DBS and OCBC reported strong Q3 results, boosting analyst confidence, while UOB faced a dimmer outlook due to increased loan provisions. All three banks may face margin pressures as interest rates fall and hedges expire. DBS's hedging strategy has mitigated the impact of lower rates so far, but its NIM is expected to decline. UOB's earnings could rebound as credit costs normalize, thanks to its provision buffers.

title: S. Korea, U.S. finalize tariff, security agreement
description: SEOUL, Nov. 14 (Xinhua) ‚Äî South Korea and the United States on Friday finalized their tariff and security agreement by announcing a joint fact sheet on summit talks between South Korean President Lee Jae-myung and U.S. President Donald Trump on Oct. 29. The agreement included 150 billion U.S. dollars of South Korean investment in the [...]
content: SEOUL, Nov. 14 (Xinhua) ‚Äî South Korea and the United States on Friday finalized their tariff and security agreement by announcing a joint fact sheet on summit talks between South Korean President Lee Jae-myung and U.S. President Donald Trump on Oct. 29.The agreement included 150 billion U.S. dollars of South Korean investment in the shipbuilding sector approved by the United States and 200 billion dollars of additional South Korean investment, according to a memorandum of understanding about strategic investments, in exchange for lower U.S. tariffs.The U.S. will apply a reciprocal tariff rate of 15 percent on originating goods of South Korea, reduce sectoral tariffs on automobiles, auto parts, timber, lumber and wood derivatives of South Korea to 15 percent, and apply no greater than 15 percent to pharmaceuticals of South Korea.The United States also intended to remove supplemental tariffs imposed on products on the list of the Potential Tariff Adjustments for Aligned Partners, including generic pharmaceuticals, generic pharmaceutical ingredients and natural resources unavailable in the United States, as well as certain aircraft and parts of South Korea.South Korea‚Äôs Yonhap News Agency noted that the fact sheet did not specify when the United States will lower the current 25 percent tariff on automobiles and auto parts to 15 percent.Industry experts in South Korea believe that even with the tariff agreement, the burden on the country‚Äôs companies in the affected sectors will not ease immediately. Citing a source in the Korean auto industry, the EToday news website reported that it will take at least one to two months for the effects of the tariff reduction to be felt, meaning that companies will continue to face significant short-term liquidity pressure.Yonhap‚Äôs analysis pointed out that Korean automobile exports to the United States had previously enjoyed zero tariffs, and determining how to cope with the impact of U.S. tariffs on South Korea‚Äôs automotive industry will be a new challenge. Kim Pill-soo, a professor at Daelim University College, stressed that fundamentally, the U.S. tariff issue has not disappeared.Regarding the so-called modernized alliance, the U.S. reaffirmed its pledge to provide extended deterrence, while South Korea shared its plan to increase its defense spending to 3.5 percent of its gross domestic product as soon as possible.South Korea also shared its plan to provide comprehensive support for the U.S. Forces Korea amounting to 33 billion dollars in accordance with Seoul‚Äôs legal requirements while committing to spending 25 billion dollars on U.S. military equipment purchases by 2030.The United States gave approval for South Korea to build nuclear-powered attack submarines.
creator: AGENCIES
ai_summary: South Korea and the United States finalized a tariff and security agreement, including 150 billion U.S. dollars of South Korean investment in the shipbuilding sector and 200 billion dollars in additional investments. The U.S. will lower tariffs on various South Korean goods, including automobiles and pharmaceuticals, to 15 percent, and remove supplemental tariffs on certain products. The agreement aims to ease the burden on South Korean companies, although immediate relief is not guaranteed.

title: SBI backs another wave of bank mergers
description: SBI controls about one quarter of India‚Äôs ‚Çπ194 lakh crore loan market
content: State Bank of India (SBI) is supportive of another wave of mergers among state-backed lenders as policymakers explore ways to build scale and finance growth in the world‚Äôs fastest-growing major economy. ‚ÄúSome further rationalisation might make sense. There are still some smaller, sub-scale banks,‚Äù Challa Sreenivasulu Setty, chairman of the country‚Äôs biggest bank, said in an interview with Bloomberg News in Mumbai. ‚ÄúIf another round happens, it may not be a bad idea,‚Äù he said. Mumbai-based SBI controls about one quarter of India‚Äôs ‚Çπ194 lakh crore ($2.18 trillion) loan market. A wave of local mergers over the past decade has left 12 state lenders competing with private and foreign players such as HDFC Bank Ltd and HSBC Holdings Plc. With a balance sheet of $787 billion, SBI dominates the industry, along with its more than 22,500 branches and over 500 million customers. India is discussing options to create large state lenders, which aligns with the government‚Äôs need to fund massive infrastructure and industrial projects in Asia‚Äôs third-largest economy. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has set a target to transform India into a developed economy by 2047. That vision requires bank financing to increase to about 130 per cent of gross domestic product from 56 per cent currently, supporting an expected ten-fold increase in GDP to roughly $30 trillion. Currently, only SBI and HDFC Bank rank in the top 100 global sector list by total assets. China and the US have rivals among the 10 biggest, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. While China and India have been saddled with some of the steepest US tariffs under President Donald Trump, New Delhi is undertaking reforms including tax cuts to lure foreign investments and take advantage of a rejig in global supply chains. Setty, who took the top job at the bank in late 2024, said that though exports had been impacted by additional US tariffs, SBI is yet to see major issues in any sector. ‚ÄúWe are not pruning any exposure, we continue to support exporters. If any temporary adjustments or facility extensions are needed, we‚Äôre addressing those,‚Äù he said. SBI, which is 55 per cent-owned by the government, is seeing signs of an industry-wide revival of capital spending by corporates but pricing for loans is becoming tighter. ‚ÄúThere are many banks looking to build corporate portfolios, but only a limited number of large corporates ‚Äî so that segment will remain highly competitive,‚Äù said Setty. Last month, the lender raised its forecast for credit growth to 12 per cent to 14 per cent for its current year from a previous guidance of 11 per cent to 12 per cent. Setty, a SBI veteran of nearly 40 years, has had a humble start. From the age of 12, he spent his school vacations collecting debts for his father‚Äôs grocery store in the small south Indian village of Potlapadu. At the state-owned bank, one of Setty‚Äôs key tasks after the coronavirus lockdown was to head recovery of SBI‚Äôs nearly $20 billion bad-loan pile. According to Setty, SBI is keen to expand its market share further. ‚ÄúEven as a dominant player, our approach isn‚Äôt about defending market share but acquiring more,‚Äù he said, adding that he doesn‚Äôt see competition from foreign capital as a threat. The firm has total assets of nearly ‚Çπ69 lakh crore, with HDFC Bank taking the second spot at ‚Çπ40 lakh crore. A wave of billion-dollar deals in India‚Äôs banking sector has put the financial sector in the global spotlight as investors seek opportunities in the country. This builds on the momentum of foreign players investing in insurance and fintech firms. SBI‚Äôs shares have gained 19 per cent over the past one year versus a 16 per cent increase in the Nifty Bank index. At the same time, authorities have proposed a framework enabling lenders to directly fund corporate takeovers, a move expected to boost the country‚Äôs $40 billion-plus deals market. The draft guidelines ensure that no bank will have excessive exposure to M&A lending, according to Setty. ‚ÄúAs for pricing, I expect some softening since more players, especially Indian lenders with access to lower-cost funds, will enter this space, he said. ‚ÄúHowever, M&A financing shouldn‚Äôt be treated like simple balance sheet funding. Each deal carries distinct risks, and pricing should reflect that, Setty said. As the country becomes a global hotspot for wealth management, banks are ramping up offerings and hiring aggressively to meet booming demand on the back of robust equity markets and real estate transactions. The firm hired 1,000 wealth relationship managers over the last 12 months, said Setty, adding that 2,000 roles were created internally to cater to its wealth customers. Setty said the financier has identified more than 110 micro-markets, mostly located in India‚Äôs metro and large urban centres, where it has opened so-called wealth hubs for clients. It plans to add another 50 to 100 hubs over the next two years. More stories like this are available on bloomberg.com Published on November 14, 2025
creator: Bloomberg
ai_summary: State Bank of India (SBI) supports another round of mergers among state-backed lenders in India to build scale and finance growth. SBI, controlling about a quarter of India's ‚Çπ194 lakh crore loan market, sees potential benefits in further rationalization of smaller banks. The move aligns with India's goal to become a developed economy by 2047, requiring bank financing to increase significantly. SBI, with a $787 billion balance sheet, is a dominant player alongside HDFC Bank, both ranking in the top 100 global sector list by total assets.

title: US Stocks Brief: Trump Readies Tariff Cuts, Trade Deals in Affordability Push, Bloomberg reporting
Jaguar Land Rover plunges to loss after heavy cyber attack costs
description: JLR booked ¬£196 million of extra costs linked to the cyber attack and ¬£42 million related to voluntary redundancies.
content: Jaguar Land Rover has plunged to a heavy loss after booking almost ¬£200 million in costs linked to a major cyber attack which saw the firm shut its factories for more than a month. The UK‚Äôs largest car manufacturer said it has ‚Äúmade strong progress‚Äù in recovering its operations at pace since the attack. JLR stopped production across its UK factories for five weeks from September 1 after being targeted by hackers a day earlier. All of the group‚Äôs manufacturing sites ‚Äì including factories in Solihull, West Midlands, and Halewood, Merseyside ‚Äì restarted operations last month. However, it saw revenues plummet by more than ¬£1 billion, around 24%, to ¬£4.9 billion for the quarter to September. It also swung to an underlying loss of ¬£485 million over the quarter, sliding from a profit before tax and exceptional items of nearly ¬£400 million over the same period in 2024. In the update, it booked ¬£196 million of extra costs linked to the cyber attack and ¬£42 million related to voluntary redundancies. The company said its performance was also impacted by US tariffs and a planned wind down in the production of previous Jaguar models.
creator: Henry Saker-Clark
ai_summary: Jaguar Land Rover reported a significant loss after a cyber attack led to a shutdown of its UK factories for over a month, resulting in ¬£196 million in extra costs and a ¬£1 billion drop in revenues. The company also faced ¬£42 million in voluntary redundancy costs, with additional impacts from US tariffs and the winding down of previous Jaguar models.
